original_data.question: A 27-year-old female presents to her physician with a palpable thyroid nodule. Iodine uptake testing shows that the nodule has decreased iodine uptake compared with the rest of the thyroid gland. A fine-needle aspiration is performed and the physician calls telling the patient that she has a neoplasm of the thyroid. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely?

model_response:
The patient has a cold nodule of the thyroid, which is more likely to be malignant than a hot nodule. Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy, accounting for about 80% of cases. It is more common in women and in younger age groups. The disease is usually unifocal. The cells have nuclei with characteristic grooves, and psammoma bodies may be present. Papillary carcinoma has an excellent prognosis, with a greater than 95% 10-year survival rate. Medullary carcinoma (choice B) is derived from the parafollicular cells and is associated with elevated serum calcitonin levels. It occurs in multiple endocrine neoplasia type II. Follicular carcinoma (choice C) is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It tends to be more aggressive than papillary carcinoma, with a 5-year survival rate of only 50-70%. Anaplastic carcinoma (choice D) is usually fatal within a few months of presentation. It is more common in older age groups.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.

A small circumscribed mass in the THYROID GLAND that can be of neoplastic growth or non-neoplastic abnormality. It lacks a well-defined capsule or glandular architecture. Thyroid nodules are often benign but can be malignant. The growth of nodules can lead to a multinodular goiter (GOITER, NODULAR).
A small lump, swelling or collection of tissue.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.

A nonmetallic element of the halogen group that is represented by the atomic symbol I, atomic number 53, and atomic weight of 126.90. It is a nutritionally essential element, especially important in thyroid hormone synthesis. In solution, it has anti-infective properties and is used topically.
The examination of two or more people or things in order to detect similarities and differences.

A highly vascularized endocrine gland consisting of two lobes joined by a thin band of tissue with one lobe on each side of the TRACHEA. It secretes THYROID HORMONES from the follicular cells and CALCITONIN from the parafollicular cells thereby regulating METABOLISM and CALCIUM level in blood, respectively.
The removal of tissue or fluid with a thin needle for examination under a microscope.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
New abnormal growth of tissue. Malignant neoplasms show a greater degree of anaplasia and have the properties of invasion and metastasis, compared to benign neoplasms.

A highly vascularized endocrine gland consisting of two lobes joined by a thin band of tissue with one lobe on each side of the TRACHEA. It secretes THYROID HORMONES from the follicular cells and CALCITONIN from the parafollicular cells thereby regulating METABOLISM and CALCIUM level in blood, respectively.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
